column6: IUCN Red List species and national conversation list species with habitats in areas affected by operations

column7: Selected Scope 3 (indirect) emissions in our value chain are monitored and reported where they are material and relevant under the Australian Climate Active Carbon Neutral Standard for Organisations, in line with the GHG Protocol Value Chain Standard categories. We acknowledge the increasing interest of stakeholders in value chain GHG emission measurements, which reflect progress in economy-wide, systemic decarbonisation through corporate initiatives. We are working to improve the transparency of our Scope 3 emissions.
This year, NEXTDC recorded a CUE of 1.16.
NEXTDC's operations and approach to carbon emissions are compliant with the Australian Federal Government's National Greenhouse and Energy Reporting (NGER) Act 2007

column8: Qantas Future Planet (QFP) carbon offset program
column13: Forming a strategic partnership with Qantas, NEXTDC became the first data centre operator in the region to achieve carbon-neutral corporate operations by purchasing carbon credits through the Qantas Future Planet (QFP) carbon offset program. In November 2018, NEXTDC was certified as a carbon-neutral organisation under the Australian Federal Government's Climate Active Carbon Neutral Standard, a partnership between the Australian Government and businesses to encourage voluntary climate action.
column20: Strategic Partnership, Carbon Neutral, Carbon Credits

column13: In March 2021, we launched NEXTneutral, a certified carbon-neutral colocation solution. Under our NEXTneutral program, we extend our Climate Active-accredited partnerships to our customer ecosystem. NEXTneutral allows customers to leverage our investment in becoming Australia's only Climate Active certified Data Centre provider.
column20: NEXTneutral, Colocation Solution, Climate Active

column13: In November 2018, NEXTDC was certified as a carbon-neutral organisation under the Australian Federal Government's Climate Active Carbon Neutral Standard, a partnership between the Australian Government and businesses to encourage voluntary climate action. First granted for the FY18 reporting period, NEXTDC has renewed its corporate organisational certification each financial year through the audit and certification of its carbon inventory and the voluntary retirement of an equal volume of carbon credits, similarly certified under Climate Active, by the producers of these credits.
column20: Carbon Neutral Organisation, Climate Active Standard, Carbon Inventory

column6: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column13: Our "Zero-Waste Initiative" focuses on separating waste through coloured bins at all sites and encouraging the reuse of office supplies and universal waste collection by leveraging our e-waste system. Every facility enables customers to dispose of their retired equipment for free, knowing we will responsibly dispose of them.
column20: Zero-Waste Initiative, Waste Separation, Universal Waste Collection

column6: Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column13: In FY23, our diesel engine oil was repurposed into other petroleum-based products through the service of specialised contractors for oil collection & disposal. It helps protect the environment while offsetting Australia's crude oil requirements.
column20: Oil Collection, Environmental Protection, Waste Repurposing

column13: Our waste hierarchy reflects the principles of a circular economy. Our Waste Management Plan and the Hazardous Materials Management Procedure manage all waste generated across NEXTDC's operations.
column20: Circular Economy, Waste Management Plan, Hazardous Materials

column8: TRUE (Total Resource Use and Efficiency) Certification
column13: In August 2023, NEXTDC's S1 Sydney became the first data centre in Australia to achieve the TRUE (Total Resource Use and Efficiency) Certification, a comprehensive certification program recognising our efforts to minimise non-hazardous solid wastes and maximising the efficient use of resources. This achievement is a significant milestone in our journey to reduce our environmental impact and further reflects our commitment. We are proud to be recognised for our efforts and will continue to work towards achieving this certification at all our sites.
column20: TRUE Certification, Resource Efficiency, Environmental Impact

column7: NEXTDC produced 156,95 tonnes of waste during FY23
125.05 tonnes being recycled and saved from going into landfill

column6: Non-compliance with environmental laws and regulations
column7: NEXTDC has not received any fines or non-monetary sanctions for non-compliance with environmental laws or regulations and is unaware of any environmental or related licensing breaches. Similarly, NEXTDC has not received fines or non-monetary sanctions for other laws.

column6: New suppliers that were screened using environmental criteria
column13: A key focus area of our sustainability strategy is to understand better the environmental and social impacts of our purchase decisions. We recognise the need to integrate sustainability considerations into our procurement processes better. In awarding contracts, NEXTDC prioritises suppliers demonstrating best practices as part of the due diligence process.
column20: Sustainability Strategy, Procurement Processes, Supplier Due Diligence

column6: Negative environmental impacts in the supply chain and actions taken
column7: We have systems in place to ensure the integrity of the Code is maintained. Where appropriate, suppliers are subject to a competitive selection process that evaluates their experience, sustainability practices, qualifications, depth of quality assurance, demonstrable financial viability, and comprehensive insurance coverage. Being a responsible business that manages its social and environmental issues and responsibilities through its supply chain remains a focus for NEXTDC.

column6: New employee hires and employee turnover
column13: NEXTDC's Hour of Power sessions aim to allow our employees to increase their knowledge and skills in specific business areas and give visibility on current business projects, systems and processes. The sessions are held bi-monthly, run for 60 minutes, and are presented by team members and external guest speakers.
column20: Hour of Power, Knowledge Sharing, Employee Development

column6: Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
column13: As part of helping more Australians retire comfortably, the Australian Government announced a further increase of 0.5% to the Superannuation Guarantee Contribution (SGC) effective 1 July 2023. In keeping with our approach last year when the contribution increased, NEXTDC has again continued to absorb the additional 0.5% superannuation without any impact on our employees' take-home pay.\t
column20: Superannuation Guarantee Contribution, Employee Benefits, Financial Wellness

column6: Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
column13: NEXTDC also has a purchased leave scheme that allows employees to fund an additional leave period (up to a maximum of four weeks per year). Purchased leave is paid at the reduced purchased leave rate, and no leave loading is payable on additional leave. This benefit allows employees to spend more time with their family, travel, get married, renovate their house or take some extra time to refresh and recharge.
column20: Purchased Leave Scheme, Work-Life Balance, Flexible Work Arrangements

column13: Our paid Parental Leave Policy extends to the birth or adoption of a child, staff members who endured the tragedy of stillbirth or infant death, as well as where adoption or surrogacy is involved. We also offer 10 keeping-in-touch days for staff on parental leave to ensure a smooth and comfortable transition back to the workplace.
column20: Parental Leave Policy, Family Support, Work-Life Integration

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
Occupation health and safety management system
column7: NEXTDC Board oversees the WHS Policy and risk framework, including regulatory and other requirements. The Company has a WHS Committee, which meets monthly to review WHS matters and consult with NEXTDC's employees, represented on the Committee for each site or office through a Health and Safety Representative (HSR). The HSRs support our organisation in identifying and managing WHS risks at the facility level and providing WHS-related advice and support at the site level.

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: NEXTDC continues to improve the standard of our new facilities by embracing lessons learned during the design, construction and operation phases of all our sites. These insights are consolidated into our "Lessons Learned Register", which now contains over 500 line items. Our Safety in Design process captures these lessons to be reviewed by every project team as part of our site design process and to ensure they are addressed with engineering solutions as far as possible. This process promotes improved systems and capabilities that strengthen our safety performance and culture.
column20: Lessons Learned Register, Safety in Design, Safety Performance

column13: We have a range of benefits to support our employees in managing their physical and mental health, including Bupa Corporate Health Cover and Health Assessments, Health and Mindfulness Webinars, Annual Flu Vaccinations, Healthy Snacks and Fruit.
column20: Employee Health Benefits, Wellbeing Support, Mental Health Initiatives

column13: Through our partnership with Sonder, NEXTDC has taken its mental health and wellbeing strategy to the next level by offering a holistic approach to keeping our people and their families safe and healthy. Sonder provides our people and their families with real-time access to a team of medical, mental health and safety experts ready to assist with their wellbeing needs, 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.
column20: Sonder Partnership, Holistic Wellbeing, Real-time Support

column6: Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
column13: The Head of Safety meets with the Board as and when required to present and discuss Safety matters. In FY23, the NEXTDC's executive team commenced periodic site visits as part of the Senior Leadership Interactions program (SLI) to discuss safety observations and opportunities for improvement with our operational staff.
column20: Safety Governance, Board Oversight, Executive Engagement

column6: Worker training on occupational health and safety

column13: Finding the time to completely switch off from work and spend time with family and friends to be your best self at home and work is essential. We encourage all Australia-based employees to take annual leave regularly and consider purchasing extra leave using their pre-tax salary.
column20: Annual Leave, Work-Life Balance, Time Off

column13: To further evolve our approach to promoting positive mental health in the workplace and supporting team members, our trained volunteer Mental Health First Aid Officers (MHFAO) are readily available to help someone experiencing a mental health problem. We have MHFAO at most sites, with more volunteers being trained. Our MHFAOs complete the Mental Health First Aid course delivered by an accredited instructor and hold a current Mental Health First Aid Australia certificate.
column20: Mental Health First Aid Officers, Mental Health Support, Workplace Wellbeing

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: WHS policies and procedures are regularly reviewed and updated based on a continuous improvement methodology. NEXTDC's WHS team and external auditors conduct regular audits and safety inspections of all data centre sites to ensure a practical WHS control framework.
column20: WHS Policies, Safety Audits, Continuous Improvement

column6: Workers covered by an occupational health and safety management system
column7: NEXTDC complies with and is accredited to the ISO 45001 WHS Management System and ISO14001 Environment Management System. Our management system is underpinned by the plan-do-check-act cycle.
We experienced a Total Recordable Injury Frequency Rate (TRIFR) of 2.1 for FY23. This was due to one recordable injury caused by improper lifting techniques and inappropriate storage location.
